question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be sure to ensure that the generated code is executable for demonstration. I want to create an Excel spreadsheet for employees to fill in their daily work plans, with a perpetual calendar for selecting dates. It should have 7 windows displaying Monday through Sunday, where daily work plans can be entered. All employees will use the same spreadsheet, but it should be possible to select individual employees to view their work plans.

checklist.title: Is the perpetual calendar fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the calendar component accurately handles date selection, supports month/year navigation, and properly highlights weekends/holidays. Check if it correctly maps selected dates to the appropriate day-of-week columns. Score 0 if the calendar is not implemented, 5 if basic date picking works but has issues with edge cases (month boundaries, leap years), and 10 if it handles all date scenarios correctly including proper month/year transitions.

checklist.title: Is the 7-day work plan display correctly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the spreadsheet properly renders 7 columns for Monday through Sunday, with correct date headers for each day. Check that the system correctly populates content based on the selected week, with appropriate styling for current day, weekend days, and holidays. Deduct 5 points if days are mislabeled or inconsistently formatted; deduct 3 points if column widths are not optimized for content. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the employee selection and filtering functionality complete?
checklist.description: Check if the code implements a robust employee selection system that allows filtering work plans by specific employees. Verify that the dropdown/selection mechanism is functional, includes search capabilities for larger employee lists, and properly persists the selected employee across date changes. Deduct 5 points if employee filtering doesn't maintain state when navigating between weeks; deduct 3 points if there's no visual indication of which employee is currently selected. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the work plan entry system allow for proper data input and management?
checklist.description: Assess whether the system provides appropriate cell editing capabilities for entering work plans, with features like text formatting, multi-line input, and character limits. Check if the implementation includes data validation, auto-save functionality, and undo/redo capabilities. Deduct 5 points if there's no data persistence mechanism; deduct 3 points if editing capabilities are limited to basic text input without formatting. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as invalid date inputs, concurrent edits by multiple users, browser compatibility issues, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Automated task tracking with completion indicators 2. Integration with notification systems for deadlines 3. Work plan templates for quick entry 4. Visual workload indicators across the week). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple date pickers with different behaviors) 2. Function modules unrelated to work planning (e.g., a built-in game) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., excessive animations when switching between employees). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data/view/controller layers), code reusability, and maintainability. Deduct 5 points if global variable pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if there is no error handling or logging mechanism. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional spreadsheet design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the spreadsheet follows professional design principles: 1) Clean grid layout with consistent cell sizing 2) Proper visual hierarchy with distinct headers and data areas 3) Professional color coding system (e.g., for weekends, current day, or priority tasks). Deduct 3 points for inconsistent cell formatting, 5 points for poor contrast making content difficult to read, and 5 points for cluttered or confusing layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and intuitive?
checklist.description: Judge whether interactions match spreadsheet user expectations: 1) Cell selection and editing behaves similarly to Excel 2) Calendar selection is immediate and visible 3) Employee switching maintains context and position. Deduct 5 points for unintuitive navigation between dates or employees, 3 points for laggy input response when entering work plans, and 5 points for missing keyboard shortcuts for common operations. The full score is 10 points.
